= Homarus gammarus = Homarus gammarus , known as the European lobster or common lobster , is a species of &lt; unk &gt; lobster from the eastern Atlantic Ocean , Mediterranean Sea and parts of the Black Sea .
It is closely related to the American lobster , H. americanus .
It may grow to a length of 60 cm ( 24 in ) and a mass of 6 <unk> ( 13 <unk> ) , and bears a <unk> pair of claws .
In life , the lobsters are blue , only becoming &quot; lobster red &quot; on <unk> .

Homarus gammarus is a highly <unk> food , and is widely caught using lobster <unk> , mostly around the British Isles .

= M @ - @ 82 ( Michigan highway ) = M @ - @ 82 is a state trunkline in the Lower Peninsula in the US state of Michigan that travels between &lt; unk &gt; and Howard City .
The section between &lt; unk &gt; and Howard City travels through &lt; unk &gt; and along the southern edge of &lt; unk &gt; National Forest .
The current version of M @ - @ 82 is actually the second in the state ; the first usage appeared in the Upper Peninsula by 1919 .
The Lower Peninsula routing has been in use since the 1920s .
<unk> <unk> and &lt; unk &gt; have shifted the terminus as far west as New <unk> or &lt; unk &gt; in the past .
The current route was <unk> in the late 1970s = = Route description = = M @ - @ 82 begins at a junction with M @ - @ 120 and B @ - @ 96 west of &lt; unk &gt; .
This junction is at a &lt; unk &gt; of county lines .
M @ - @ 120 forms the north – south &lt; unk &gt; – &lt; unk &gt; and &lt; unk &gt; – &lt; unk &gt; county lines .
B @ - @ 96 , which forms the east – west &lt; unk &gt; – &lt; unk &gt; county line runs due west of the intersection .
M @ - @ 82 exits the intersection to the east .
The highway runs along <unk> Street through rural <unk> into the community of &lt; unk &gt; .
The road , now called Main Street , passes through the downtown area and M @ - @ 82 turns south along <unk> Avenue out of town .
The highway <unk> a <unk> and <unk> to <unk> Street running eastward through more <unk> land .
As the trunkline approaches &lt; unk &gt; , the terrain becomes more <unk> near the &lt; unk &gt; River .
M @ - @ 82 follows &lt; unk &gt; Street east to a junction with M @ - @ 37 .
The two highways merge and run concurrently over the river and into downtown on State Street .
South of downtown , M @ - @ 82 turns east again , independent of M @ - @ 37 , and runs along <unk> Street on the southern edge of the &lt; unk &gt; National Forest .
The east end of M @ - @ 82 is at exit <unk> on US 131 / M @ - @ 46 west of Howard City .
The Michigan Department of Transportation ( MDOT ) , as a part of its maintenance <unk> , tracks the volume of traffic using its roadways .
These levels are expressed in terms of a <unk> called average annual daily traffic ( <unk> ) , which is a <unk> of the traffic along a segment of road for any average day of the year .
In 2009 , the department &apos; s <unk> indicated that a segment of M @ - @ 82 west of &lt; unk &gt; had the peak volume for the highway at 16 @ , @ &lt; unk &gt; vehicles daily .
The traffic <unk> was 4 @ , @ &lt; unk &gt; vehicles east of &lt; unk &gt; .
In addition , MDOT has not had any section of the highway listed on the National Highway System , a network of roads important to the country &apos; s economy , defense , and mobility .
= = History = = = = = <unk> designation = = = The first usage of M @ - @ 82 was in the Upper Peninsula by July 1 , 1919 .

= = = <unk> designation = = = The current M @ - @ 82 dates back to 1926 .
It ran from US 31 in <unk> to the northern junction of US 131 and M @ - @ 46 in Howard City .
The highway was routed through <unk> , &lt; unk &gt; and &lt; unk &gt; , replacing M @ - @ 41 .
In late 1936 , M @ - @ 46 was extended along the section between &lt; unk &gt; and Howard City , forming a M @ - @ 46 / M @ - @ 82 concurrency to fill a gap in the M @ - @ 46 routing .
This concurrent section became just M @ - @ 46 in 1938 , &lt; unk &gt; M @ - @ 82 back to the northern M @ - @ 37 junction in &lt; unk &gt; .
The highway was moved to a new alignment west of <unk> in late 1947 or early 1948 .

Two &lt; unk &gt; in 1963 and 1964 rerouted the western end of the highway again .

A larger change around 1969 &lt; unk &gt; the highway designations in &lt; unk &gt; County .
M @ - @ 20 replaced M @ - @ 82 west of &lt; unk &gt; , to end at New <unk> instead of &lt; unk &gt; .

M @ - @ 46 was rerouted to follow the US 131 freeway south of Howard City to <unk> Springs , and replaced M @ - @ 57 between <unk> Springs and &lt; unk &gt; .
This <unk> up the &lt; unk &gt; to Howard City highway for a return to the M @ - @ 82 designation .

= Meridian , Mississippi = Meridian is the sixth largest city in the state of Mississippi , in the United States .
It is the county seat of Lauderdale County and the principal city of the Meridian , Mississippi &lt; unk &gt; <unk> Area .
Along major highways , the city is 93 mi ( 150 km ) east of Jackson , Mississippi ; <unk> mi ( &lt; unk &gt; km ) west of Birmingham , Alabama ; 202 mi ( <unk> km ) northeast of New Orleans , Louisiana ; and <unk> mi ( 372 km ) southeast of Memphis , Tennessee .
<unk> in 1860 , at the intersection of the Mobile and Ohio Railroad and Southern Railway of Mississippi , Meridian &apos; s economy was built on the <unk> and goods transported on them , and it became a strategic trading center .
During the American Civil War , General William &lt; unk &gt; Sherman burned much of the city to the ground in the Battle of Meridian ( February , <unk> ) .
&lt; unk &gt; after the war , the city entered a &quot; Golden Age &quot; it become the largest city in Mississippi between 1890 and 1930 , and a leading center for manufacturing in the South , with 44 <unk> arriving and departing daily .
Union Station , built in 1906 , is now a multi @ - @ <unk> center , giving access to the Meridian Transit System , &lt; unk &gt; &lt; unk &gt; , and &lt; unk &gt; , <unk> <unk> @ , @ 360 passengers per year .
Although the economy slowed with the decline of the railroad industry , the city has <unk> , with healthcare , military , and manufacturing employing the most people in 2010 .
The population within the city limits , according to 2008 census estimates , is 38 @ , @ 232 , but a population of 232 @ , @ 900 in a 45 @ - @ mile ( 72 km ) radius and <unk> @ , @ 500 in a 65 @ - @ mile ( 105 km ) radius , of which 104 @ , @ 600 and <unk> @ , @ 200 people respectively are in the labor force , <unk> the economy of the city .
The area is served by two military facilities , Naval Air Station Meridian and Key Field , which provide over 4 @ , @ 000 jobs .
&lt; unk &gt; Meridian is home to the Regional <unk> @ - @ &lt; unk &gt; Training Academy ( &lt; unk &gt; ) and the first local Department of <unk> Security in the state .
Key Field is named after brothers Fred and Al Key , who set a world endurance flight record in 1935 .
The field is now home to the <unk> Air &lt; unk &gt; Wing of the Air National Guard and a support facility for the &lt; unk &gt; Aviation Brigade of the Army National Guard .
Rush Foundation Hospital is the largest non @ - @ military <unk> in the region , employing 2 @ , @ 610 people .
Among the city &apos; s many arts organizations and historic buildings are the Riley Center , the Meridian Museum of Art , Meridian Little Theatre , and the Meridian Symphony Orchestra .
Meridian was home to two Carnegie libraries , one for whites and one for African Americans .
The Carnegie Branch Library , now demolished , was one of a number of Carnegie libraries built for blacks in the Southern United States during the segregation era .
The city has been selected as the future location of the Mississippi Arts and Entertainment Center ( &lt; unk &gt; ) .
&lt; unk &gt; &lt; unk &gt; , the &quot; <unk> of Country Music &quot; , was born in Meridian .
Highland Park houses a museum which displays &lt; unk &gt; of his life and career , as well as railroad equipment from the steam @ - @ engine era .
The park is also home to the Highland Park &lt; unk &gt; &lt; unk &gt; , a National Historic <unk> .
It is the world &apos; s only two @ - @ row <unk> &lt; unk &gt; <unk> in existence .

= = History = = <unk> <unk> by the &lt; unk &gt; Native Americans , the area now called Meridian was obtained by the United States under the terms of the Treaty of <unk> &lt; unk &gt; Creek in <unk> during the period of Indian &lt; unk &gt; .
After the treaty was <unk> , European @ - @ American settlers began to move into the area .
After receiving a federal land <unk> of about 2 @ , @ 000 acres ( &lt; unk &gt; ha ) , Richard &lt; unk &gt; , the first <unk> of Meridian , began offering free land to <unk> to attract more settlers to the region and develop the area .
Most of &lt; unk &gt; &apos; s land was bought in 1853 by Lewis A.
&lt; unk &gt; , a <unk> from Alabama .
John T. Ball , a merchant from &lt; unk &gt; County , bought the remaining 80 acres ( 0 @ .
@ 32 km2 ) .
&lt; unk &gt; and Ball , now known as the <unk> of the city , began <unk> out lots for new development on their respective land sections .
There was much competition over the proposed name of the settlement .
Ball and the more industrial residents of the city supported the name &quot; Meridian , &quot; believing the term to be <unk> with &quot; junction &quot; ; the more <unk> residents of the city preferred &quot; &lt; unk &gt; &quot; ( meaning &quot; <unk> river &quot; in a Native American language ) , from the name of a nearby creek ; and &lt; unk &gt; proposed &quot; &lt; unk &gt; City . &quot;
Ball erected a station house on the Mobile and Ohio Railroad – the sign on which would alternate between &quot; Meridian &quot; and &quot; &lt; unk &gt; &quot; each day .
Eventually the continued development of the railroads led to an <unk> of railroad workers who <unk> the others in the city and left &quot; Meridian &quot; on the station <unk> .
The town was officially incorporated as Meridian on February 10 , 1860 .
Meridian was a small village at the start of the American Civil War in 1861 .
Its strategic position at the railroad junction led to the Confederate construction of several military <unk> to support the war .
During the Battle of Meridian in <unk> , General William &lt; unk &gt; Sherman led troops into the city , destroying the railroads in every direction , as well as an <unk> and <unk> &lt; unk &gt; ; his forces burned much of the buildings to the ground .
Sherman is reported to have said afterwards , &quot; Meridian , with its <unk> , store @ - @ houses , <unk> , <unk> , offices , hotels , and &lt; unk &gt; no longer exists . &quot;
Despite the <unk> , the railroad lines in the city were rapidly repaired , back in operation 26 working days after the battle .
Race relations remained <unk> during the Reconstruction era , with the <unk> of <unk> following a fire that damaged many businesses .
The town &lt; unk &gt; in the aftermath of the Civil War , and experienced its &quot; Golden Age &quot; from <unk> to 1910 .
The railroads in the area provided for a means of transportation and an <unk> of industries , which caused a population <unk> .
As the population rose , commercial activity increased in the downtown area .
Between 1890 and 1930 , Meridian was the largest city in Mississippi and a leading center for manufacturing in the South .
Many of the city &apos; s historic buildings were built during and just after this era , including the Grand <unk> House in 1890 , the &lt; unk &gt; School in 1894 , two Carnegie libraries in 1913 , and the &lt; unk &gt; Building , Meridian &apos; s tallest <unk> , in 1929 .
The city continued to grow thanks to a commission government &apos; s efforts to bring in 90 new industrial plants in 1913 and a <unk> <unk> industry in the 1920s .
Even through the stock market crash of 1929 and the following Great Depression , the city continued to attract new businesses .

The federal &lt; unk &gt; was built in 1933 as a &lt; unk &gt; project .
After a brief &lt; unk &gt; of the economy at the end of the Depression , the country entered World War II , which renewed the importance of railroads .
The rails were essential to transport <unk> and <unk> metal to build military vehicles , so Meridian became the region &apos; s rail center again .
This renewed <unk> continued until the 1950s , when the <unk> and Interstate Highway System became more popular than passenger rails .
The decline of the railroad industry caused significant job losses , resulting in a population decline as workers left for other areas .
During the American Civil Rights Movement in the 1960s , Meridian was home to a Council of &lt; unk &gt; &lt; unk &gt; ( &lt; unk &gt; ) office and several other activist organizations .

<unk> in the area resented the <unk> , and racial <unk> often resulted in violence .

Starting in the 1960s and following the construction of highways that made &lt; unk &gt; easier , residents began to move away from downtown in favor of new housing <unk> to the north .
After strip commercial interests began to move downtown , the city worked to <unk> several areas as historic districts in the 1970s and <unk> to preserve the architectural character of the city .
The Meridian Historic &lt; unk &gt; and <unk> Commission was created in 1979 , and the Meridian Main Street program was founded in 1985 .
Meridian Main Street organized several projects to &lt; unk &gt; downtown , including the construction of a new Amtrak Station in 1997 based on the design of the historic train station used during Meridian &apos; s Golden Age ; it had been demolished .

= = = <unk> = = = Given Meridian &apos; s site as a railroad junction , its <unk> have attracted the development of many hotels .
Even before Meridian reached its &quot; Golden Age , &quot; several large hotels , including the Great Southern and the Grand Avenue hotels , were built before the start of the 20th century .
With the growth of the railroads and the construction of the original Union Station in 1906 , many hotels were constructed for passengers and workers .
The &lt; unk &gt; Hotel was constructed in <unk> , and the <unk> Hotel was constructed in 1910 .
Hotel Meridian was constructed in 1907 , and Union Hotel was built in 1908 .
Union Hotel was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1979 , and both Hotel Meridian and Grand Avenue Hotel were listed as <unk> <unk> to the Meridian Urban Center Historic District .
As the city grew , the hotels <unk> <unk> of the strong economy , as <unk> by the <unk> @ - @ story <unk> Lamar Hotel built in 1927 .
<unk> on the National Register of Historic Places in 1979 , the Lamar Hotel was adapted for use as a county <unk> building .
In 1988 it was listed as a Mississippi <unk> .
The &lt; unk &gt; Young Hotel was built in <unk> .
A <unk> in the African @ - @ American business district that developed west of the city &apos; s core , the hotel was one of the only places in the city during the years of segregation where a <unk> African American could find a room .
As the city <unk> developed in the 1960s and &apos; <unk> , most hotels moved outside of downtown .
&lt; unk &gt; of the Riley Center in 2006 has increased demand and a push for a new downtown hotel .
The &lt; unk &gt; Building has been proposed for redevelopment for this purpose , but restoration efforts <unk> with a change in city <unk> .

= = = Historic districts = = = Meridian has nine historic districts that are listed on the National Register of Historic Places .

= = = Air = = = The city is served by Meridian Regional Airport , located at Key Field , &lt; unk &gt; Airport <unk> South , 3 mi ( 4 @ .
@ 8 km ) southwest of the city .
At 10 @ , @ &lt; unk &gt; foot ( 3 @ , @ &lt; unk &gt; m ) , the airport &apos; s <unk> is the longest public <unk> in Mississippi .
The airport , which has been in service since 1930 , offers daily flights to Dallas / Fort <unk> , &lt; unk &gt; .
During the Great Depression , residents of the city <unk> <unk> the airport because of the cost of maintenance , but in 1935 Brothers Fred and Al Key , <unk> of the airport , thought of a way to keep the airport operating .
From June 4 until July 1 , 1935 , the brothers flew over the city in their plane , the &quot; <unk> Miss . &quot;
The record they established in their 27 days &lt; unk &gt; , totaling <unk> hours and 34 minutes , attracted enough <unk> and funds to the city to keep the airport running .
Key Field is therefore named after the brothers , whose flight endurance record remains <unk> in conventional flight .

= = <unk> = = Early public education in Meridian was based on the 1870 Mississippi Constitution .
From 1870 to 1885 , <unk> appointed by the City Council served on the Board of School <unk> , which had authority to operate the schools .
Although there were several schools in the city before 1884 , they were <unk> owned and only enrolled about 400 students .
The city did not build its first publicly owned school until September 1884 .
The first public school for blacks in the city was held in facilities <unk> from St. Paul <unk> Church .
The Mississippi <unk> <unk> the city <unk> in January 1888 to allow the city to <unk> its own <unk> school district , and in March of the same year $ 30 @ , @ 000 in <unk> was approved for the city to build new public schools .
From this <unk> , the &lt; unk &gt; School was built in 1894 , becoming the first <unk> public school building in the state built for blacks .
From this early district and later <unk> , the Meridian Public School District grew to its current size , which now includes six <unk> schools , 3 middle schools , and 3 high schools .
The city also contains several private schools including Lamar School , &lt; unk &gt; Christian School , Community Christian School , and St. Patrick &apos; s <unk> School .
The <unk> of Meridian High School , the main high school in the district , <unk> 37 acres ( 15 ha ) , including six buildings and 111 <unk> .
The school is made up of <unk> 10 @ - @ 12 and &lt; unk &gt; approximately 1 @ , @ 500 students .
Meridian is home to two post @ - @ secondary <unk> institutions .
Meridian Community College , founded in 1937 , is located at 910 Highway 19 N and offers free <unk> for four &lt; unk &gt; to <unk> from the Meridian Public and Lauderdale County School &lt; unk &gt; as well as &lt; unk &gt; children who <unk> inside Lauderdale County .
Originally known as Meridian Junior College and located at Meridian High School , the college moved to its present location in 1965 .
After &lt; unk &gt; laws were passed , &lt; unk &gt; <unk> with &lt; unk &gt; Harris Junior College in 1970 , which had previously enrolled African @ - @ American students .
The name change from Meridian Junior College to Meridian Community College took place In 1987 &quot; to more <unk> reflect the <unk> of opportunities it provides for a growing community area . &quot;
Mississippi State University also operates a <unk> in the city .
As of the <unk> 2008 <unk> , <unk> students from 33 counties throughout the state and several in Alabama attended the college .
Meridian is served by the Meridian @ - @ Lauderdale County Public Library , located at the corner of 7th Street and <unk> Avenue .
The city originally had two Carnegie libraries , both built in 1913 – one for blacks and one for whites .
A group of women had formed the &lt; unk &gt; <unk> and Magazine Club in the 1880s and began raising money to build a library for the city .
The books they collected and shared within the club were later the basis of the library collection for Meridian .
With wide support for the library , the club enlisted Israel <unk> , a city leader , to approach the national <unk> Andrew Carnegie for funding assistance .
The library for blacks was built at 13th Street and 28th Avenue on land donated by St. Paul <unk> Church , and the library for whites was established in a building originally owned by members of the First <unk> Church of Meridian , who sold it to the city on September 25 , 1911 .
The African American library was the only library for blacks in the state until after World War I and is the only Carnegie library ever built for African Americans in the country .
The two libraries served the city until 1967 , when the institutions became integrated because of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 , combined their <unk> , and moved all materials to their current location .
The former white library was <unk> and converted into the Meridian Museum of Art in 1970 , and the former African @ - @ American library was demolished on May 28 , 2008 .

= Angel of Death ( Slayer song ) = &quot; Angel of Death &quot; is the opening track on the American <unk> metal band Slayer &apos; s 1986 album Reign in Blood .

= The &lt; unk &gt; Blues = &quot; The &lt; unk &gt; Blues &quot; is a blues song by American <unk> and blues musician , Lead &lt; unk &gt; .
It was written in June 1937 in response to the discrimination and segregation that Lead &lt; unk &gt; faced during a visit to Washington , DC to record for Alan &lt; unk &gt; .
It rails against racism , the Jim <unk> laws , and the conditions of contemporary African Americans in the southern United States .
The song was recorded in December 1938 for the Library of Congress and re @ - @ recorded in 1939 for commercial release .
It has been remixed and covered by a number of artists including Pete <unk> , &lt; unk &gt; &lt; unk &gt; , <unk> &lt; unk &gt; , and Billy Bragg . &quot;
The &lt; unk &gt; Blues &quot; is <unk> as one of Lead &lt; unk &gt; &apos; s best original works , but it also drew controversy .
There is <unk> over the song &apos; s <unk> , with some scholars &lt; unk &gt; that Lead &lt; unk &gt; was unlikely to have written a work in a <unk> new to him without a <unk> .
&lt; unk &gt; have been raised over his role in the American Communist Party and whether he and the song were used to further the party &apos; s political goals .
= = Background and creation = = Most music <unk> date the writing of &quot; The &lt; unk &gt; Blues &quot; to Lead &lt; unk &gt; &apos; s June 1937 trip to Washington , DC , when he was invited by the &lt; unk &gt; Alan &lt; unk &gt; to record for the Library of Congress &apos; s <unk> music collection .
On the first night Lead &lt; unk &gt; and his wife <unk> spent in the city , they encountered <unk> &lt; unk &gt; Jim <unk> laws similar to those found in their native Louisiana : most hotels refused to <unk> rooms to African Americans and the few that would were either full or refused to serve him because he was with a white man ( &lt; unk &gt; ) .
&lt; unk &gt; , in some versions of the story described as an <unk> &quot; white friend &quot; , offered to let the couple stay for the night in his apartment near the Supreme Court Building .
The next morning , Lead &lt; unk &gt; &lt; unk &gt; to &lt; unk &gt; <unk> with his &lt; unk &gt; about the presence of a black man , with the &lt; unk &gt; threatening to call the police .
While in Washington , Lead &lt; unk &gt; encountered several other incidents of segregation that are believed to have contributed to the &lt; unk &gt; of the song .
For instance , when Lead &lt; unk &gt; , &lt; unk &gt; , and their <unk> wanted to go out to dinner together , they discovered that it was impossible for the mixed race group to find a <unk> that would serve them .
Lead &lt; unk &gt; was told that if he returned later without &lt; unk &gt; , he would be served .
In response to one of these incidents , a friend of Lead &lt; unk &gt; &apos; s , <unk> identified as either &lt; unk &gt; or Mary Elizabeth &lt; unk &gt; <unk> that Washington was a &quot; &lt; unk &gt; town . &quot;
Though Lead &lt; unk &gt; did not know what the word &quot; &lt; unk &gt; &quot; meant , he was <unk> by the sound of it , and after its meaning was explained to him he decided to <unk> it into a song about the trip .
The song came together quickly ; one account claims that it only took a few hours for Lead &lt; unk &gt; to write it .
&lt; unk &gt; liked it because it was partly based on what happened in his apartment .
= = <unk> , themes and music = = &quot; The &lt; unk &gt; Blues &quot; is a blues @ - @ style protest song that <unk> the culture of Washington , DC .
It <unk> against both the city &apos; s Jim <unk> laws and the racism of its white population .
Its structure includes several verses and a <unk> that <unk> that the speaker is going to &quot; spread the news all around &quot; about the racial issues &lt; unk &gt; the city .
The song , particularly in the <unk> , &lt; unk &gt; race and <unk> by referring to &lt; unk &gt; as &quot; &lt; unk &gt; &quot; .
The first two verses speak of the segregation that Lead &lt; unk &gt; encountered in Washington DC : the first <unk> the fact that during the trip , Lead &lt; unk &gt; was &quot; turned down &quot; <unk> he tried to get served due to his race , while the second <unk> the <unk> between &lt; unk &gt; and his &lt; unk &gt; over Lead &lt; unk &gt; staying in his apartment .
The third verse &lt; unk &gt; <unk> &quot; the home of the <unk> , the land of the Free &quot; , <unk> with the <unk> he received at the hands of white people in Washington , DC .
The fourth verse <unk> of the racism of the white population of the city , leading to the song &apos; s end , which suggests that African Americans <unk> <unk> homes in the district .
The song &apos; s <unk> <unk> that the speaker <unk> <unk> against the discrimination and racism that he encounters ; despite this , by &quot; <unk> the news &quot; of his poor treatment in a song , the speaker uses what power he has to tell both southern African Americans and northern whites that the status &lt; unk &gt; is deeply <unk> and that something needs to change . &quot;
The &lt; unk &gt; Blues &quot; follows a traditional twelve @ - @ bar blues <unk> .
It is written in 44 time but &lt; unk &gt; to note that the song &lt; unk &gt; should <unk> at <unk> &lt; unk &gt; .
The song was written in B ♭ .
It uses twelve <unk> with verses one to four repeating , followed by the final two verses and a &lt; unk &gt; .
= = <unk> and &lt; unk &gt; = = Lead &lt; unk &gt; first recorded &quot; The &lt; unk &gt; Blues &quot; in December 1938 in New York City , for donation to the Library of Congress .

<unk> at the junction of the <unk> B. Johnson <unk> ( Interstate 635 , I @ - @ 635 ) and the Central Expressway ( US Highway 75 , US 75 ) , it <unk> an &lt; unk &gt; <unk> cloverleaf interchange constructed in the 1960s .
The $ <unk> million project was started in 2002 and completed in December 2005 .
It was designed by the &lt; unk &gt; Corporation and built by &lt; unk &gt; Construction Corporation .
The interchange is considered by <unk> &lt; unk &gt; to be one of &quot; The World &apos; s 18 &lt; unk &gt; &lt; unk &gt; &quot; because of its height ( as high as a 12 @ - @ story building ) , its 43 permanent bridges and other unusual design and construction features .
In 2006 , the American Public Works Association named the High Five Interchange as &quot; Public Works &lt; unk &gt; of the Year &quot; .
= = Description = = The High Five Interchange , north of downtown in Dallas , Texas , is a massive five @ - @ level freeway interchange .
It is the junction of two major highways carrying heavy <unk> hour traffic , the <unk> B. Johnson <unk> ( Interstate 635 ) and the Central Expressway ( US 75 ) , and is the first five @ - @ level <unk> interchange to be built in the city .
It <unk> the &lt; unk &gt; three @ - @ level , modified cloverleaf interchange built in the 1960s that caused a severe <unk> by <unk> US 75 down to two lanes at the junction of the two highways .
The <unk> ramps of the cloverleaf forced <unk> to slow down <unk> , <unk> up traffic .
<unk> @ - @ hand exits contributed to the <unk> .
Further , its two <unk> roads were not directly connected to each other , making local access difficult .
&lt; unk &gt; to the <unk> <unk> , the &quot; High Five &quot; name refers to the five <unk> ramps <unk> the left @ - @ turn movements that tower over the <unk> .
The interchange is as high as a 12 @ - @ story building , and includes 43 bridges spread across five levels ( the &quot; High Five &quot; ) , <unk> support <unk> , and 60 miles of additional highway .
The highest ramps are 120 feet ( 37 m ) above ground .
The lanes of US 75 , which are on the bottom level , are 20 feet ( 6 m ) below ground level , giving the structure a total height of 140 feet from bottom to top As part of the project , I @ - @ 635 was <unk> to include four dedicated high @ - @ <unk> <unk> lanes ( &lt; unk &gt; lanes ) that are <unk> @ - @ separated and &lt; unk &gt; .
The roads on the five levels are : Level I : US 75 , an eight lane highway , four lanes going each way Level II : The junction of the two six @ - @ lane <unk> roads , each having three through lanes in each direction , left @ - @ turn lanes and &lt; unk &gt; , and easy access to US 75 and I @ - @ 635 Level III : I @ - @ 635 , ten regular lanes , five going each way , and four &lt; unk &gt; lanes ( two going each way ) separated by <unk> Level IV and V : <unk> connection ramps ( two levels ) , <unk> the left exits of the modified cloverleaf The interchange , with its decorative &lt; unk &gt; on &lt; unk &gt; concrete elements , along with the <unk> <unk> <unk> <unk> by the Texas Department of Transportation ( &lt; unk &gt; ) , can be <unk> as an <unk> work of public art .
The High Five also <unk> a hiking and <unk> trail , named the &lt; unk &gt; Trail , which runs under all levels of the interchange .
The section of the trail passing beneath the interchange was constructed as part of the High Five project by &lt; unk &gt; .
The interchange is considered by <unk> &lt; unk &gt; as one of &quot; The World &apos; s 18 &lt; unk &gt; &lt; unk &gt; &quot; , calling it a &quot; <unk> of lanes &quot; and a &quot; five @ - @ level &lt; unk &gt; of engineering &quot; because of its height , the number of its bridges and other unusual design and construction features .
= = History = = The High Five Interchange project was planned as a replacement for the existing , &lt; unk &gt; interchange that <unk> 500 @ , @ 000 vehicles daily and was located in one of the most <unk> developed commercial zones in Dallas .
It was a <unk> project between the &lt; unk &gt; , <unk> <unk> and property owners , and the primary <unk> , &lt; unk &gt; Construction .
An essential <unk> was to complete the project with as little <unk> to the traffic flow as possible .
<unk> for <unk> the interchange , in addition to the need to increase traffic flow and reduce <unk> , were to improve air quality , safety , and local access .
&lt; unk &gt; Construction Corporation submitted the lowest bid and was awarded the $ <unk> million contract by &lt; unk &gt; , the largest ever by that agency .
The construction contract for the High Five Interchange was unique in that it contained elements not found in other construction project <unk> .
For example , it <unk> the concrete maturity <unk> to be used to ensure the concrete &apos; s strength ( the first time &lt; unk &gt; had ever done so ) , and contained an early completion bonus , a &lt; unk &gt; scale of up to $ 11 million if the company completed the contract within four years .
Also built into the construction contract was a <unk> that &lt; unk &gt; was charged for &quot; lane <unk> &quot; by &lt; unk &gt; for time they closed down traffic lanes — <unk> based on &lt; unk &gt; <unk> and the time of day the lane was closed .
The <unk> <unk> from $ 50 to a high of $ 110 @ , @ 000 for <unk> hours .
In order not to <unk> with traffic flow during construction , the new interchange was designed largely as <unk> <unk> ramps and &lt; unk &gt; so they could be built high over the existing junction lanes ; once traffic was transferred to the new structures the old lanes could simply be closed off and removed .
Little of the original interchange remained when the project was finished .
To <unk> time and money , <unk> construction methods were employed : The original plans called for the segments of the long ramps and <unk> ( used to direct @ - @ <unk> roads ) to be made of steel , but because building with steel would <unk> with heavy traffic flow during construction , cast @ - @ in @ - @ place <unk> concrete was <unk> in the plans .
However , &lt; unk &gt; decided to use &lt; unk &gt; concrete <unk> bridges , rather than casting the bridge elements in place , and used a unique machine , designed and constructed by <unk> &lt; unk &gt; of Italy and <unk> about $ 1 million , to move the pieces into place .
During the construction , 2 @ .
@ 2 million <unk> yards of &lt; unk &gt; was used , 350 @ , @ 000 <unk> yards of concrete was mixed on site , and 300 @ , @ 000 square feet of <unk> walls were built .
Additionally , 40 @ , @ 000 feet of <unk> <unk> and 75 @ , @ 000 <unk> feet of <unk> pipe were completed .
In addition to the construction of 43 permanent bridges , six temporary bridges were built , resulting in 2 @ .
@ 3 million square feet of bridge deck .
The project was designed by the &lt; unk &gt; Corporation who provided professional engineering <unk> throughout the construction , which had begun in 2002 and was completed in December 2005 , more than 13 months <unk> than planned .
= = Awards = = In 2006 , the American Public Works Association named the High Five &quot; Public Works Project of the Year &quot; for its massive size , its <unk> design , the <unk> and &lt; unk &gt; of its construction and the need it <unk> for the community .

= Tim Richmond = Tim Richmond ( June 7 , 1955 – August 13 , 1989 ) was an American race car driver from &lt; unk &gt; , Ohio .
He competed in &lt; unk &gt; racing before <unk> to &lt; unk &gt; &apos; s Winston Cup Series ( now &lt; unk &gt; Cup Series ) .
Richmond was one of the first drivers to change from open wheel racing to &lt; unk &gt; stock cars full @ - @ time , which has since become an industry <unk> .
He won the 1980 Indianapolis 500 Rookie of the Year award and had 13 victories during eight &lt; unk &gt; seasons .
Richmond achieved his top &lt; unk &gt; season in 1986 when he finished third in points .
He won seven races that season , more than any other driver on the tour .
When he missed the season @ - @ opening &lt; unk &gt; 500 in February 1987 , media reported that he had <unk> .

= = Geography = = The &lt; unk &gt; Creek Mountains are in a very remote area of southeastern Oregon and northern Nevada , in <unk> and <unk> counties .

= = <unk> = = The mountains lie within the Basin and Range Province or Great Basin of the Western United States , which is <unk> by a series of parallel <unk> blocks that form long north – south mountain ranges separated by wide , high @ - @ desert <unk> .
The &lt; unk &gt; Creek Mountains are &lt; unk &gt; and &lt; unk &gt; blocks with <unk> &lt; unk &gt; along the southern and eastern sides of the range .

The &lt; unk &gt; Creek Mountains are composed mostly of <unk> from a <unk> <unk> that once stood where &lt; unk &gt; Mountain is today .

= New Jersey Route 29 = Route 29 is a state highway in the U.S. state of New Jersey .
It runs 34 @ .
@ 76 mi ( 55 @ .
@ 94 km ) from an interchange with Interstate 295 ( I @ - @ 295 ) in Hamilton Township in <unk> County , where it continues as I @ - @ 195 , to Route 12 ( Bridge Street / Race Street ) in Frenchtown , &lt; unk &gt; County .
Between the southern terminus and I @ - @ 95 , the route is a mix of freeway and four @ - @ lane divided highway that runs along the Delaware River through &lt; unk &gt; .
This section includes a <unk> @ - @ <unk> tunnel that was built along the river near historic houses and &lt; unk &gt; Cemetery .
North of I @ - @ 95 , Route 29 turns into a <unk> and mostly two @ - @ lane highway .
North of the South &lt; unk &gt; <unk> , it is designated the Delaware River Scenic Byway , a New Jersey Scenic Byway and National Scenic Byway , that follows the Delaware River in mostly rural sections of <unk> County and &lt; unk &gt; County .
The <unk> Delaware &amp; &lt; unk &gt; Canal usually stands between the river and the highway .
Most sections of this portion of Route 29 are completely &lt; unk &gt; due to the tree <unk> .
Route 29 also has a spur , Route 129 , which connects Route 29 to U.S. Route 1 ( US 1 ) in &lt; unk &gt; .
Route 29 was initially designated in 1927 to run from downtown &lt; unk &gt; to Newark , following present @ - @ day Route 179 and US 202 between &lt; unk &gt; and &lt; unk &gt; and US 22 between &lt; unk &gt; and Newark .
The route between &lt; unk &gt; and Frenchtown was originally Route &lt; unk &gt; .
In 1953 , Route 29 was shifted to follow the alignment of Route &lt; unk &gt; to avoid the &lt; unk &gt; with the U.S.
<unk> .
Route 29 between South Warren Street in &lt; unk &gt; and I @ - @ 95 in Ewing Township was upgraded to a four @ - @ lane highway , with a portion of freeway , in the 1950s and 1960s .
In 1995 , the southern freeway part of Route 29 between I @ - @ 195 / I @ - @ 295 and Route 129 in Hamilton Township was completed .
This freeway section was linked to the rest of Route 29 by a tunnel completed in 2002 .
A <unk> of Route 29 in &lt; unk &gt; by the <unk> made the route concurrent with the entire length of 0 @ .
@ 26 @ - @ mile @ - @ long ( 0 @ .
@ 42 km ) Route 165 .
= = Route description = = = = = <unk> County = = = Route 29 begins at a modified cloverleaf interchange with Interstate 195 and Interstate 295 in Hamilton Township , and it serves as the western <unk> of Interstate 195 , heading to the northwest as a six @ - @ lane freeway .
The route <unk> with Route 129 , a spur of Route 29 which connects to U.S. Route 1 , at a <unk> interchange with a northbound exit and southbound entrance .
Route 29 &lt; unk &gt; to four lanes past this interchange and crosses into &lt; unk &gt; .
The route comes to a southbound exit and entrance for &lt; unk &gt; Road .
At this point , Route 29 becomes the Delaware River Scenic Byway , a state <unk> &lt; unk &gt; that was also designated a National Scenic Byway in 2009 .
Route 29 runs along the bank of the Delaware River and enters a <unk> @ - @ <unk> tunnel that passes by historic houses and &lt; unk &gt; Cemetery .
Within this tunnel , Route 29 features a southbound exit and northbound entrance for <unk> Street .
The route <unk> from the tunnel as the John <unk> Parkway , passes by <unk> &amp; &lt; unk &gt; Park , and comes to a traffic light at Thunder Road / <unk> Street where it &lt; unk &gt; back to six lanes .
Route 29 meets South Warren Street at another traffic light .
The median &lt; unk &gt; and it passes under the &lt; unk &gt; @ - @ &lt; unk &gt; Railroad Bridge , which carries the Amtrak <unk> <unk> over the Delaware River .

= = History = = The current route was originally <unk> in 1911 as part of the Delaware River Drive , a named state highway that was proposed to run from along the Delaware River from &lt; unk &gt; to the New York border in &lt; unk &gt; Township .
Route 29 was originally defined in 1927 to run from &lt; unk &gt; to Newark .
The original route ran from downtown &lt; unk &gt; along State Street and &lt; unk &gt; Drive .
From there , it followed its current alignment to &lt; unk &gt; , where it followed present @ - @ day Route 179 to &lt; unk &gt; to present @ - @ day County Route &lt; unk &gt; , which it followed to <unk> <unk> .
The route turned north on U.S. Route <unk> ( also designated Route 31 ) and followed that route to &lt; unk &gt; , where it followed U.S. Route 22 to Newark .

The alignment of Route 29 between &lt; unk &gt; and &lt; unk &gt; was eventually shifted to follow present @ - @ day U.S. Route 202 , which was also Route 30 ( now Route 31 ) between &lt; unk &gt; and <unk> and Route 12 between <unk> and &lt; unk &gt; .
In 1938 , Route &lt; unk &gt; was planned as an extension of Route &lt; unk &gt; from Frenchtown to Route 28 ( now Route <unk> ) in <unk> .
While this road was never built , much of the alignment north of <unk> is served by County Route &lt; unk &gt; .
In 1948 , a spur route , Route &lt; unk &gt; , was created , running along U.S. Route 202 ( Bridge Street ) in &lt; unk &gt; to the New <unk> @ - @ &lt; unk &gt; Bridge .
In the 1953 New Jersey state highway <unk> , Route 29 was &lt; unk &gt; to continue north from &lt; unk &gt; to Frenchtown on Route &lt; unk &gt; , and the Route 29 designation between &lt; unk &gt; and Newark was removed in favor of U.S. Route 202 between &lt; unk &gt; and &lt; unk &gt; and U.S. Route 22 between &lt; unk &gt; and Newark .

Plans for a limited @ - @ access route along the Route 29 corridor go back to 1932 , when a <unk> was proposed along the Delaware River between &lt; unk &gt; and &lt; unk &gt; ; this <unk> never <unk> .
Plans for a freeway were <unk> in the early 1950s to <unk> a road , the John <unk> Parkway , that was to run from Hamilton Township to Interstate 95 in Ewing Township .

= = Background = = = = = Pagan and &lt; unk &gt; = = = In the 13th century , the Pagan Empire , along with the <unk> Empire , was one of the two main <unk> in mainland Southeast Asia .

= = Legacy = = The war was one of several near <unk> wars &lt; unk &gt; by the &lt; unk &gt; Empire and the Yuan dynasty in the late 13th century .

= = = Age of political <unk> = = = The immediate result of the war was the collapse of the Pagan Empire .

= Battle of &lt; unk &gt; &apos; s Ridge = The Battle of &lt; unk &gt; &apos; s Ridge , also known as the Battle of the <unk> Ridge , Battle of Raiders Ridge , and Battle of the Ridge , was a land battle of the Pacific campaign of World War II between Imperial Japanese Army and Allied ( mainly United States Marine Corps ) ground forces .
It took place from 12 – 14 September 1942 , on &lt; unk &gt; in the Solomon Islands , and was the second of three separate major Japanese ground offensives during the &lt; unk &gt; Campaign .
In the battle , U.S. Marines , under the overall command of U.S. Major General Alexander &lt; unk &gt; , repulsed an attack by the Japanese <unk> Infantry Brigade , under the command of Japanese Major General &lt; unk &gt; &lt; unk &gt; .
The Marines were defending the &lt; unk &gt; perimeter that <unk> Henderson Field on &lt; unk &gt; , which was captured from the Japanese by the Allies in landings on &lt; unk &gt; on 7 August 1942 .
&lt; unk &gt; &apos; s unit was sent to &lt; unk &gt; in response to the Allied landings with the mission of &lt; unk &gt; the airfield and driving the Allied forces from the island .
&lt; unk &gt; the strength of Allied forces on &lt; unk &gt; – about 12 @ , @ 000 – &lt; unk &gt; &apos; s 6 @ , @ 000 soldiers conducted several <unk> frontal <unk> on the U.S. defenses .

&lt; unk &gt; .

= = Background = = = = = &lt; unk &gt; campaign = = = On 7 August 1942 , Allied forces ( primarily U.S. ) landed on &lt; unk &gt; , &lt; unk &gt; , and Florida Islands in the Solomon Islands .
The landings on the islands were meant to <unk> their use by the Japanese as bases for threatening the supply routes between the U.S. and Australia .
They were also intended to secure the islands as starting points for a campaign to <unk> the major Japanese base at Rabaul and support the Allied New Guinea campaign .
The landings <unk> the six @ - @ month @ - @ long &lt; unk &gt; campaign .
<unk> the Japanese by surprise , by <unk> on 8 August the Allied landing forces had secured &lt; unk &gt; and nearby small islands , as well as an airfield under construction at &lt; unk &gt; Point ( 9 ° 25 ′ 45 ″ S 160 ° 3 ′ 4 ″ E ) on the north <unk> of the island of &lt; unk &gt; east of the present day capital of &lt; unk &gt; .
&lt; unk &gt; placed his 11 @ , @ 000 troops of the 1st Marine Division on &lt; unk &gt; in a loose perimeter around the &lt; unk &gt; Point area .
On 12 August , the airfield was named Henderson Field after Major &lt; unk &gt; Henderson , a Marine &lt; unk &gt; who had been killed at the Battle of <unk> .

= = = &lt; unk &gt; movement = = = On 28 August , 600 of &lt; unk &gt; &apos; s troops were loaded onto the destroyers &lt; unk &gt; , &lt; unk &gt; , &lt; unk &gt; , and &lt; unk &gt; , designated <unk> Division 20 ( &lt; unk &gt; ) .

= = &lt; unk &gt; = = On 15 September , General &lt; unk &gt; at Rabaul learned of &lt; unk &gt; &apos; s defeat , the Imperial Japanese Army &apos; s first defeat involving a unit of this size in the war .

&lt; unk &gt; <unk> that , in order to send <unk> troops and <unk> to defeat the Allied forces on &lt; unk &gt; , he could no longer support the major Japanese offensive on the &lt; unk &gt; Track in New Guinea .
&lt; unk &gt; — with the &lt; unk &gt; of the General Headquarters — ordered his troops on New Guinea , who were within 30 mi ( 48 km ) of their objective of Port <unk> — to withdraw until the &lt; unk &gt; matter was <unk> .

After <unk> more forces during the next month the Japanese mounted a major ground offensive on &lt; unk &gt; , led by &lt; unk &gt; , in late October 1942 at the Battle for Henderson Field , but it resulted in an even more <unk> defeat for the Japanese .
&lt; unk &gt; later stated that &lt; unk &gt; &apos; s assault on the ridge in September was the only time during the entire campaign he had <unk> about the <unk> and that had it succeeded , &quot; we would have been in a <unk> bad condition . &quot;

= New Jersey Route 50 = Route 50 is a state highway in the southern part of the U.S. state of New Jersey .
It runs 26 @ .
@ 02 mi ( 41 @ .
@ 88 km ) from an intersection with U.S. Route 9 ( US 9 ) and the Garden State Parkway in Upper Township , Cape May County to an intersection with US 30 and County Route &lt; unk &gt; ( CR &lt; unk &gt; ) in &lt; unk &gt; Harbor City , Atlantic County .

= = History = = The portion of current Route 50 between &lt; unk &gt; and <unk> received funding to become a spur of the Ocean Highway in 1910 .
The modern @ - @ day alignment of Route 50 was <unk> as part of pre @ - @ 1927 Route 14 in 1917 , a route that was to run from Cape May to &lt; unk &gt; Harbor City .
In the 1927 New Jersey state highway <unk> , the portion of pre @ - @ 1927 Route 14 between &lt; unk &gt; and &lt; unk &gt; Harbor City was designated as Route 50 , the highest state route number assigned in the <unk> .
Route 50 retained its current routing in the 1953 New Jersey state highway <unk> .
A freeway was proposed for Route 50 around 1960 , running from the Garden State Parkway in Dennis Township north to US 30 in &lt; unk &gt; Township .
This proposed freeway was intended to provide economic development to the region as well as provide a better route to the Jersey <unk> <unk> of Cape May County for <unk> from the Delaware Valley .
However , this freeway was canceled by the mid @ - @ 1970s due to financial and environmental concerns as well as lack of traffic along Route 50 .
On November 21 , 2008 , construction began on making the interchange with the Atlantic City Expressway a full interchange as part of a series of <unk> set for the Atlantic City Expressway .
This project was completed on June 18 , 2010 .

= = Site description = = &lt; unk &gt; has been partially restored by the University of Pennsylvania and the government of Guatemala .

= = = <unk> = = = There are thousands of ancient structures at &lt; unk &gt; and only a <unk> of these have been excavated , after decades of archaeological work .

= Tropical Storm &lt; unk &gt; ( 2008 ) = Tropical Storm &lt; unk &gt; was the tenth tropical storm of the 2008 Atlantic hurricane season .
&lt; unk &gt; developed out of a strong tropical wave which moved off the African coast on August 31 .
The wave quickly became organized and was declared Tropical Depression Ten while located <unk> mi ( <unk> km ) to the south @ - @ southeast of the Cape Verde Islands on September 2 .
The depression was quickly upgraded to Tropical Storm &lt; unk &gt; around <unk> the same day .
Over the next several days , &lt; unk &gt; moved in a general west @ - @ northwest direction and reached its peak intensity early on September 3 .
<unk> wind shear , some due to the <unk> of Hurricane <unk> , and dry air caused the storm to <unk> .
On September 6 , the combination of wind shear , dry air , and <unk> waters caused &lt; unk &gt; to <unk> into a tropical depression .
&lt; unk &gt; <unk> into a remnant low shortly after as convection continued to <unk> around the storm .
The low ultimately dissipated while located <unk> mi ( <unk> km ) east of &lt; unk &gt; on September 10 .
However , the remnant <unk> led to minor flooding on the island of St. <unk> .
= = <unk> history = = Tropical Storm &lt; unk &gt; formed as a tropical wave that emerged off the west coast of Africa near the end of August 2008 .
It <unk> south of Cape Verde and slowly developed , and on September 2 the <unk> became Tropical Depression Ten while located south @ - @ southeast of the Cape Verde islands .
As the depression became more organized , an eye @ - @ like feature developed in the upper levels of the system .
The depression was upgraded to Tropical Storm &lt; unk &gt; six hours after forming .
&lt; unk &gt; was located in an area which was <unk> for rapid <unk> but was not forecast to <unk> quickly .
&lt; unk &gt; continued to <unk> throughout the afternoon as the storm became more <unk> .
However , due to the location of the storm , there was a lack of <unk> wind speed <unk> , and the National Hurricane Center was <unk> of its actual intensity .
Despite the lack of wind shear around the storm , the center became slightly exposed and ceased further <unk> .
The storm was also heading into an area where shear was &lt; unk &gt; to significantly increase due to an upper @ - @ level <unk> <unk> <unk> .
Despite convection being partially removed from the center of &lt; unk &gt; , the storm <unk> slightly in the early morning hours on September 3 as <unk> activity to the south of the center became more organized .
The <unk> was forecast to be short in <unk> as the <unk> to the north was <unk> , causing the wind shear to the west to become stronger .
&lt; unk &gt; reached its peak intensity of 65 mph ( 100 km / h ) around 8 <unk> ( &lt; unk &gt; ) as it continued to become more organized .
However , there were <unk> that it had already begun to <unk> .
&lt; unk &gt; towards the north was becoming <unk> and arc <unk> began <unk> from the storm , a sign that dry air was entering the system .
During the afternoon hours , the structure of &lt; unk &gt; began to rapidly <unk> as strong wind shear and dry air took their <unk> .

The convection around the system became &lt; unk &gt; from the center and &lt; unk &gt; weakened slightly .
The weakening <unk> continued through the afternoon as the storm was being <unk> by strong &lt; unk &gt; shear .
&lt; unk &gt; became almost fully <unk> of any convection by mid @ - @ afternoon and the storm weakened to 40 mph ( 65 km / h ) , <unk> holding on to tropical storm status .
&lt; unk &gt; <unk> a small amount of convection in the late night hours , but not enough to still be <unk> a tropical storm .
Due to the lack of convection , &lt; unk &gt; was <unk> to a Tropical Depression at &lt; unk &gt; ( &lt; unk &gt; ) with winds of 35 mph ( 55 km / h ) .

= = Background = = Scientology , founded in the early 1950s in the United States by L. Ron Hubbard and today claiming to be represented in 150 countries , has been a very controversial new religious movement .

= = <unk> status = = While there have been calls for Scientology to be banned , the Church of Scientology remains legal in Germany and is allowed to operate there .
Its <unk> legal status however is <unk> .
Two points are contested : first , whether or not the <unk> of Scientology qualify as a &quot; religion or &lt; unk &gt; &quot; ( <unk> or &lt; unk &gt; ; these are equal before German law ) , and &lt; unk &gt; , whether or not these <unk> are only used as a <unk> for <unk> commercial activity ; if the latter were the case , this would most likely <unk> that Scientology would not qualify for protection as a &quot; religious or &lt; unk &gt; community &quot; ( &lt; unk &gt; <unk> &lt; unk &gt; ) under <unk> 4 of the German constitution , which <unk> the freedom of <unk> , religion and &lt; unk &gt; .
<unk> as a &quot; religious or &lt; unk &gt; community &quot; also <unk> a broad range of other issues in Germany , such as <unk> and freedom of association .
The Federal Court of Justice of Germany has not yet made an <unk> decision on the matter , but <unk> assumed in 1980 that Scientology represented a religious or &lt; unk &gt; community .
The Upper Administrative Court in Hamburg <unk> asserted in 1994 that Scientology should be viewed as a &lt; unk &gt; community .
In 1995 , the Federal Labor Court of Germany decided that the Church of Scientology merely <unk> commercial aims and did not <unk> a religious or &lt; unk &gt; community entitled to protection under <unk> 4 of the German Constitution , although another decision by the same court left the question open again in 2003 .

In 2005 , the Federal Administrative Court of Germany <unk> granted a Scientologist protection under <unk> 4 @ .

Many courts have declined to <unk> the religious status of Scientology , finding that the question was <unk> to <unk> the case at hand .

= 1888 – 89 New Zealand Native football team = The 1888 – 89 New Zealand Native football team was a New Zealand rugby <unk> team that toured Britain , Ireland , Australia and New Zealand in 1888 and 1889 .
It mostly comprised players of Māori ancestry , and also included some &lt; unk &gt; ( white New Zealanders ) .
A <unk> private &lt; unk &gt; , the tour was not under the <unk> of any official rugby authority ; it was organised by New Zealand international player Joseph &lt; unk &gt; , promoted by civil <unk> Thomas &lt; unk &gt; , and managed by James Scott , a &lt; unk &gt; .
The &lt; unk &gt; were the first New Zealand team to perform a &lt; unk &gt; , and also the first to wear all black .
They played <unk> rugby matches during the tour , as well as a small number of Victorian Rules football and association football matches in Australia .
<unk> made a significant impact on the development of New Zealand rugby , the &lt; unk &gt; were <unk> into the International Rugby Board Hall of Fame in 2008 .
After a <unk> tour of New Zealand in 1888 , the side travelled to England via Melbourne and Suez .
The Māori players initially provoked <unk> due to their race , but the British press subsequently expressed some surprise that the side was not as &quot; Māori &quot; as they had expected .
<unk> their first match , on 3 October against Surrey , the team was <unk> to a <unk> match schedule , and frequently played three matches per week .
Their early matches included a 9 – 0 loss to Middlesex , but their form improved in November , when they won 10 of their 13 matches .
The team played its first international match on 1 December , against Ireland , and won 13 – 4 .
This was followed by a win over one of the strongest English county teams , Yorkshire , and a 5 – 0 defeat against the Wales national team .
By January 1889 the &lt; unk &gt; had played 36 matches in less than three months , winning 22 of them ; they had spent most of their time in the north of England , where the playing strength was strongest and the <unk> largest and most <unk> .
In a return match on 19 January , Yorkshire <unk> a stronger side than in the first match and inflicted one of the &lt; unk &gt; &apos; <unk> losses , a 16 – 4 defeat .
The team then went <unk> until 16 February , when they faced England .
<unk> of the <unk> <unk> Rugby Football Union ( RFU ) had become increasingly concerned at the behaviour of the New Zealanders , regarding them as <unk> , and <unk> reached a <unk> in the aftermath of the England international , during which the RFU secretary George <unk> Hill , &lt; unk &gt; the game , awarded a number of controversial tries to England , prompting three of the &lt; unk &gt; to temporarily leave the field in protest ; England eventually won 7 – 0 .
The &lt; unk &gt; <unk> afterwards for their behaviour , but the damage was not repaired .
The New Zealanders left England without an official send @ - @ off , and travelled to Australia where they toured Victoria , New South Wales and Queensland .
They then returned to New Zealand , where they displayed a level of combination not seen in their home country before .
They went 31 games <unk> before losing their final match , on 24 August 1889 , 7 – 2 to Auckland .
The &lt; unk &gt; &apos; final record in rugby matches was 78 wins , 6 <unk> and 23 losses .
They introduced a number of <unk> <unk> to New Zealand rugby on their return home , and their tour contributed to the formation of the New Zealand Rugby Football Union in <unk> .
<unk> of the team &apos; s 26 players went on to play &lt; unk &gt; in New Zealand , and two , Thomas &lt; unk &gt; and David &lt; unk &gt; , subsequently <unk> the New Zealand national rugby team .
= = Background = = The idea for <unk> a team of Māori <unk> to tour Britain was conceived by Joseph &lt; unk &gt; , a rugby player who had toured with the first New Zealand national team in 1884 .
He initially proposed a team of Māori or part @ - @ Māori to play the touring British side in 1888 ; this developed into a <unk> to have a Māori team tour Britain if a <unk> tour of New Zealand were successful .
&lt; unk &gt; of &lt; unk &gt; &apos; s plans , civil <unk> Thomas &lt; unk &gt; <unk> him to offer help <unk> the tour , which &lt; unk &gt; accepted .
When James Scott , a &lt; unk &gt; , subsequently joined the <unk> , the three men decided that &lt; unk &gt; would be the team &apos; s captain , Scott its manager and &lt; unk &gt; its promoter .
&lt; unk &gt; started <unk> a team for the tour in early 1888 .

<unk> Māori or part @ - @ Māori players joined the squad ; five &lt; unk &gt; ( white New Zealand ) players were added after the team lost to Auckland .

= = &lt; unk &gt; in England and early matches = = The team were met in Britain by local rugby <unk> , including an official of England &apos; s Rugby Football Union ( RFU ) .

= = Impact and <unk> = = The tour had a significant impact on the development of rugby within New Zealand .
It was the first tour of the British Isles by a team from the Southern <unk> , and the longest in the history of the sport .

The tour also prompted the <unk> formation of the New Zealand Rugby Football Union ( &lt; unk &gt; , later renamed New Zealand Rugby Union ) in <unk> ; one reason for its formation was to ensure greater control over any future touring New Zealand sides .
The &lt; unk &gt; sent an officially <unk> New Zealand team , <unk> by &lt; unk &gt; , to tour Australia in <unk> .
The &lt; unk &gt; are also the &lt; unk &gt; of the Māori All <unk> , a representative team organised by the &lt; unk &gt; , that first played in 1910 .

= Battle of Sullivan &apos; s Island = The Battle of Sullivan &apos; s Island or the Battle of Fort Sullivan was fought on June 28 , 1776 , during the American Revolutionary War .
It took place near Charleston , South Carolina , during the first British attempt to capture the city from American <unk> .
It is also sometimes referred to as the First Siege of Charleston , <unk> to a more successful British siege in &lt; unk &gt; .
The British organized an expedition in early 1776 for operations in the <unk> southern colonies of North America .
&lt; unk &gt; by <unk> concerns and bad weather , the expedition reached the coast of North Carolina in May 1776 .
<unk> conditions <unk> for their operations , General Henry Clinton and Admiral Sir Peter Parker decided instead to act against Charleston .
<unk> there in early June , troops were landed on Long Island , near Sullivan &apos; s Island where Colonel William &lt; unk &gt; commanded a partially constructed fort , in preparation for a naval bombardment and land assault .
General Charles Lee , commanding the southern <unk> <unk> of the war , would provide <unk> .
The land assault was <unk> when the channel between the two islands was found to be too deep to &lt; unk &gt; , and the American defenses prevented an amphibious landing .
The naval bombardment had little effect due to the <unk> <unk> and the &lt; unk &gt; nature of the fort &apos; s &lt; unk &gt; <unk> construction .
&lt; unk &gt; fire by the defenders <unk> significant damage on the British fleet , which withdrew after an entire day &apos; s bombardment .
The British withdrew their expedition force to New York , and did not return to South Carolina until &lt; unk &gt; .

= = <unk> = = &lt; unk &gt; from the &apos; &apos; Ten &lt; unk &gt; Studio Manual of <unk> and &lt; unk &gt; &apos; &apos; = <unk> on Manila ( 1798 ) = The <unk> on Manila of January 1798 was a Royal Navy false flag military operation during the French Revolutionary Wars intended to <unk> the strength of the defences of Manila , capital of the Spanish Philippines , capture a Manila <unk> and <unk> the condition of the Spanish Navy squadron maintained in the port .
Spain had transformed from an ally of Great Britain in the War of the First <unk> into an enemy in 1796 .
<unk> the presence of a powerful Spanish squadron at Manila posed a threat to the China Fleet , an annual convoy of East &lt; unk &gt; merchant ships from &lt; unk &gt; in Qing <unk> China to Britain , which was of vital economic importance to Britain .

= Battle of the &lt; unk &gt; River = The Battle of the &lt; unk &gt; River took place during the Second World War and involved Australian , New Zealand and Japanese forces .
Part of the wider &lt; unk &gt; Campaign of the Pacific theatre , the battle was fought in the southern sector of &lt; unk &gt; Island .
<unk> after the Battle of &lt; unk &gt; &apos; s Knoll in which a strong Japanese <unk> was defeated , the battle occurred in two distinct <unk> between 17 April and 22 May 1945 , as elements of the Australian 15th Brigade advanced south along the &lt; unk &gt; Road .
The initial phase saw the Australians advance towards the &lt; unk &gt; River .
Following the end of the early fighting , the Australian advance towards the main Japanese concentration at &lt; unk &gt; continued as they struck out towards the &lt; unk &gt; and &lt; unk &gt; <unk> .
This continued until <unk> rain and flooding brought the advance to a halt short of the objective , &lt; unk &gt; away many bridges and roads upon which the Australians <unk> for supplies .
As the Australian advance <unk> , the Japanese began <unk> the Australian line of communications , and as the rain stopped and the flooding <unk> in late @ - @ July and into August , the Australians began making <unk> to resume the advance towards &lt; unk &gt; again .
<unk> , though , the war came to an end before the final Australian advance began , <unk> the campaign to an end .
= = Background = = = = = <unk> situation = = = Japanese forces had landed on &lt; unk &gt; in early 1942 , capturing it from the small force of Australians &lt; unk &gt; the island .
They had subsequently developed several &lt; unk &gt; on the island , using it to conduct operations in the northern Solomon Islands and to attack the Allied lines of <unk> between the United States , Australia and the <unk> Pacific Area .
These bases also helped protect Rabaul , the major Japanese garrison and naval base in <unk> New Guinea , and throughout 1943 , Allied <unk> determined that &lt; unk &gt; was vital for &lt; unk &gt; the Japanese base around Rabaul .
US Marines conducted an amphibious landing at Cape &lt; unk &gt; , on the western coast of the island , north of <unk> <unk> Bay , in November 1943 .
After an initial counter @ - @ attack , the US Marines had been replaced by a garrison of US Army troops who began <unk> their position around &lt; unk &gt; , establishing a strong perimeter .
In March 1944 , the Japanese launched a heavy counter @ - @ attack , which was turned back with heavy casualties .
After this , the situation on &lt; unk &gt; became largely <unk> , as the Japanese focused primarily on <unk> , and the US forces chose to <unk> a mainly defensive <unk> focused on maintaining the perimeter around &lt; unk &gt; .
In late 1944 , as part of plans to free US troops up for the Philippines campaign , the Australian II Corps — consisting of mainly <unk> troops under the command of Lieutenant General Stanley &lt; unk &gt; — took over responsibility for Allied operations on &lt; unk &gt; from the American <unk> Corps .
Australian forces began arriving on the island between November and December 1944 , initially establishing themselves around the US base at &lt; unk &gt; .
Due to <unk> intelligence , &lt; unk &gt; <unk> believed that the Japanese forces on the island numbered just 17 @ , @ 500 men , and he consequently decided that the Australians would pursue an aggressive campaign to clear the Japanese from &lt; unk &gt; in order to free their troops for subsequent operations elsewhere , rather than maintaining the defensive <unk> the US forces had adopted .

= Sonic the Hedgehog ( 1991 video game ) = Sonic the Hedgehog is a platform video game developed by Sonic Team and published by Sega for the Sega Genesis console .
The game was first released in North America , Europe and Australia in June 1991 , and in Japan the following month .

Sonic the Hedgehog , designed for fast gameplay , was influenced by the games of Super Mario series <unk> , <unk> <unk> .

= U.S. Route 2 in Michigan = US Highway 2 ( US 2 ) is a component of the United States &lt; unk &gt; Highway System that connects <unk> , Washington , to the Upper Peninsula ( UP ) of the US state of Michigan , with a separate segment that runs from &lt; unk &gt; Point , New York , to &lt; unk &gt; , <unk> .
In Michigan , the highway runs through the UP in two segments as a part of the state trunkline highway system , entering the state at &lt; unk &gt; and ending at St. Ignace ; in between , US 2 briefly <unk> the state of Wisconsin .
As one of the major transportation &lt; unk &gt; in the UP , US 2 is a major <unk> for traffic through the state and <unk> northern <unk> states .
Two sections of the roadway are included as part of the Great Lakes Circle &lt; unk &gt; , and other segments are listed as state @ - @ designated <unk> Michigan &lt; unk &gt; .
There are several memorial highway designations and historic bridges along US 2 that date to the &lt; unk &gt; and 1920s .
The highway runs through rural sections of the UP , passing through two national and two state forests in the process .
The route of what became US 2 was used as part of two Indian trails before European settlers came to the UP , and as part of the Michigan segments of the <unk> <unk> International Highway and the King &apos; s International Highway auto trails in the early 20th century .
The state later included these trails as part of M ‑ 12 when the first state highway &lt; unk &gt; were designated in 1919 .
Most of M ‑ 12 was <unk> as part of US 2 when the US Highway System was created on November 11 , 1926 .
Since the 1930s , several changes have &lt; unk &gt; the highway &apos; s routing through the UP .
One such <unk> eventually created a business loop that connected across the state line with <unk> , Wisconsin , and others pushed an originally inland routing of US 2 closer to the Lake Michigan <unk> .
With the creation of the Interstate Highway System , part of US 2 was rerouted to <unk> with the new Interstate 75 ( I ‑ 75 ) , though in the 1980s , the U.S. Highway was truncated and removed from the I ‑ 75 freeway , resulting in today &apos; s basic form .
= = Route description = = According to a 2006 regional planning committee report , US 2 is a key highway for Michigan , providing its main western <unk> .
The roadway plays &quot; an important role in the transportation of goods across the northern <unk> of states in the <unk> &quot; , and is listed on the National Highway System ( <unk> ) for its entire length .
The <unk> is a network of roadways important to the country &apos; s economy , defense , and mobility .
<unk> with M ‑ 28 , US 2 is part of a pair of primary &lt; unk &gt; that bridge the eastern and western sides of the UP .

= = History = = = = = Indian trail through auto trails = = = In <unk> , the first transportation routes through what became the state of Michigan were the lakes , rivers and Indian trails .
Two of these trails followed parts of the future US 2 .
The &lt; unk &gt; – Green Bay Trail roughly followed the Lake Michigan <unk> routing of US 2 between &lt; unk &gt; and St. Ignace .
The Mackinac Trail connected St. Ignace with &lt; unk &gt; &lt; unk &gt; .
Marie .
In the age of the auto trail , the roads that later formed US 2 through the UP were given a few different highway names .
When the original roadways between &lt; unk &gt; and Iron River were completed in late 1915 , the Upper Peninsula Development Bureau ( &lt; unk &gt; ) named the area &lt; unk &gt; and the highway the &lt; unk &gt; Trail .
Later the name was extended over the highway to &lt; unk &gt; , and to all highways in the area in the early 1920s ; the name was <unk> out by the &lt; unk &gt; completely in 1927 .
The roadways were also used for the <unk> <unk> International Highway , named for former US president <unk> <unk> after his death in 1919 .
Overall , this highway ran from Portland , Oregon , to Portland , <unk> , by way of Michigan and the Canadian province of Ontario .
Through the UP , the southern branch followed the immediate <unk> to US 2 , including the section through Florence County , Wisconsin .
The Great Lakes <unk> Route was established in 1917 by the &lt; unk &gt; .
A <unk> of the Great Lakes Circle &lt; unk &gt; by <unk> years , the route followed &quot; a <unk> journey along the banks of lakes Michigan and Superior and Green Bay ... &quot; This route followed the modern US 2 from &lt; unk &gt; to the M ‑ 94 junction in &lt; unk &gt; , using the modern M ‑ 69 and M ‑ 95 to stay in Michigan .
&lt; unk &gt; of the route followed US 41 and M ‑ 35 between <unk> and &lt; unk &gt; .
The route was originally intended to <unk> <unk> to drive around Lake Michigan .
The name fell out of use before its first anniversary because of World War I.
One Canadian auto trail was routed through the UP as well .
In 1920 , the King &apos; s International Highway linked Vancouver , British Columbia , to <unk> , <unk> <unk> , but there was no highway to carry it around the north side of Lake Superior .
&lt; unk &gt; had to ship their cars by boat between &lt; unk &gt; &lt; unk &gt; .
Marie , Ontario , and Thunder Bay or enter the United States to continue along the auto trail .
The &lt; unk &gt; varied on the <unk> of the time , but its basic route used US 2 through the UP from &lt; unk &gt; to &lt; unk &gt; &lt; unk &gt; .
Marie until a highway north of Lake Superior was opened in 1960 ; by that time , the auto trail had taken on the <unk> @ - @ Canada Highway name .
= = = State trunkline = = = The first state trunkline highway designated along the path of the modern US 2 was M ‑ 12 , a designation that was in use by July 1 , 1919 , between &lt; unk &gt; and &lt; unk &gt; &lt; unk &gt; .
Marie .

When the US Highway System was created on November 11 , 1926 , US 2 partially replaced M @ - @ 12 .
Between Crystal Falls and Iron Mountain , US 2 was routed through Florence , Wisconsin .
The former routing of M ‑ 12 from Crystal Falls to &lt; unk &gt; became a new M ‑ 69 when the former M ‑ 69 became US <unk> ( now US 141 ) .

Marie .

Marie ; the former routing was given the M ‑ <unk> designation .

Downtown &lt; unk &gt; was <unk> in 1934 , and the former route was initially designated M ‑ 54 .
The Michigan State Highway Department ( MSHD ) changed the &lt; unk &gt; and designations of the highways around &lt; unk &gt; , Thompson and &lt; unk &gt; in the mid @ - @ 1930s .

Further changes in the early <unk> &lt; unk &gt; the roadway out near &lt; unk &gt; and Crystal Falls .

= = = Interstate era = = = With the coming of the Interstate Highway System in Michigan , the MSHD planned to <unk> the eastern section of US 2 to a freeway between St. Ignace and &lt; unk &gt; St. Marie .

The proposed number in 1958 was Interstate 75 ( I ‑ 75 ) .
The first section of freeway was built in late 1957 or early 1958 between &lt; unk &gt; &lt; unk &gt; and M ‑ 123 north of St. Ignace .

Marie .
At this time , all of US 2 &apos; s former routing became a county road known as Mackinac Trail ( H @ - @ <unk> ) .
The Department of State Highways expanded US 2 / US 41 into an expressway between <unk> and Rapid River in 1971 .

In 2011 , MDOT raised the speed limit along the expressway section in Delta County from 55 to 65 mph ( 89 to 105 km / h ) , although the speed limit for <unk> remains 55 mph ( 89 km / h ) .
= = Memorial designations and <unk> routes = = On July 1 , <unk> , the State Administrative Board named M ‑ 12 , the <unk> to US 2 in Michigan , the &lt; unk &gt; Highway to honor Frank P. &lt; unk &gt; , a prominent local <unk> who later served in Congress from 1927 to 1933 .
In 1929 , the residents of &lt; unk &gt; created a memorial to the <unk> of World War I called <unk> <unk> .
The project consisted of &lt; unk &gt; and <unk> trees <unk> along US 2 / US 41 west of town .
The American <unk> sold the trees to local businesses and individuals who could honor specific soldiers .
Later in 1949 , the &lt; unk &gt; Women &apos; s Club created a tribute in the form of a permanent living memorial to the area <unk> .

@ 3 miles ( 3 @ .
@ 7 km ) of US 2 east of &lt; unk &gt; .

To <unk> the gap in the routing where US 2 <unk> through Wisconsin , M ‑ 95 and M ‑ 69 were used in place of US 2 between Iron Mountain and Crystal Falls .

= Military history of Australia = The military history of Australia <unk> the nation &apos; s <unk> @ - @ year modern history , from the early Australian frontier wars between &lt; unk &gt; and Europeans to the ongoing conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan in the early 21st century .
Although this history is short when compared to that of many other nations , Australia has been involved in numerous conflicts and wars , and war and military service have been significant <unk> on Australian society and national identity , including the Anzac spirit .
The relationship between war and Australian society has also been shaped by the enduring themes of Australian strategic culture and its unique security <unk> .
As British &lt; unk &gt; , the Australian colonies participated in Britain &apos; s small wars of the 19th century , while later as a &lt; unk &gt; <unk> , and then an independent nation , Australia fought in the First World War and Second World War , as well as in the wars in Korea , Malaya , Borneo and Vietnam during the <unk> War .
In the Post @ - @ Vietnam era Australian forces have been involved in numerous international peacekeeping missions , through the United Nations and other agencies , including in the Sinai , Persian Gulf , &lt; unk &gt; , <unk> , East Timor and the Solomon Islands , while more recently they have also fought as part of multi @ - @ <unk> forces in Iraq and Afghanistan .
In total , nearly <unk> @ , @ 000 Australians died during the course of these conflicts .
= = War and Australian society = = For most of the last century military service has been one of the single greatest shared experiences of white Australian <unk> , and although this is now <unk> due to the <unk> of the military and the absence of major wars during the second half of the 20th century , it continues to influence Australian society to this day .
War and military service have been <unk> <unk> in Australian history , while a major part of the national identity has been built on an &lt; unk &gt; <unk> of the Australian experience of war and of &lt; unk &gt; , known as the Anzac spirit .
These <unk> include <unk> of endurance , <unk> , <unk> , <unk> , &lt; unk &gt; , &lt; unk &gt; and &lt; unk &gt; ; <unk> which , according to popular thought , defined the behaviour of Australian soldiers fighting at Gallipoli during the First World War .
The Gallipoli campaign was one of the first international events that saw Australians taking part as Australians and has been seen as a key event in <unk> a sense of national identity .
The relationship between war and Australian society has been shaped by two of the more enduring themes of Australian strategic culture : &lt; unk &gt; with a powerful ally and <unk> warfare .

= = Colonial era = = = = = British Forces in Australia , <unk> – 1870 = = = From <unk> until 1870 the defence of the Australian colonies was mostly provided by British Army regular forces .

= = = Colonial military forces , 1870 – 1901 = = = From 1870 until 1901 , each of the six colonial governments was responsible for their own defence .

The colonial military forces included <unk> volunteer militia , paid <unk> soldiers , and a small permanent component .
They were mainly infantry , cavalry and mounted infantry , and were neither <unk> in barracks nor subject to full military <unk> .

= = Australian military forces at <unk> , 1901 = = The Commonwealth of Australia came into existence on 1 January 1901 as a result of the <unk> of the Australian colonies .

= = Second World War , 1939 – 45 = = = = = Europe and the Middle East = = = Australia entered the Second World War on 3 September 1939 .

The RAAF &apos; s resources were initially mainly <unk> to training airmen for service with the Commonwealth air forces through the Empire Air Training <unk> ( &lt; unk &gt; ) , through which almost 28 @ , @ 000 Australians were trained during the war .

During 1940 the light cruiser &lt; unk &gt; Sydney and five elderly destroyers ( <unk> the &quot; &lt; unk &gt; Iron <unk> &quot; by Nazi <unk> Minister Joseph <unk> — a title <unk> accepted by the ships ) took part in a series of operations as part of the British Mediterranean Fleet , and sank several Italian warships .
