= = = Asia and the Pacific = = = From the 1920s Australia &apos; s defence thinking was dominated by British Imperial defence policy , which was <unk> by the &quot; Singapore strategy &quot; .
This strategy involved the construction and defence of a major naval base at Singapore from which a large British fleet would <unk> to Japanese <unk> in the region .
To this end , a high proportion of Australian forces in Asia were concentrated in Malaya during 1940 and 1941 as the threat from Japan increased .
However , as a result of the emphasis on co @ - @ operation with Britain , relatively few Australian military units had been retained in Australia and the Asia @ - @ Pacific region .
<unk> were taken to improve Australia &apos; s defences as war with Japan &lt; unk &gt; in 1941 , but these proved <unk> .
In December 1941 , the Australian Army in the Pacific comprised the 8th Division , most of which was stationed in Malaya , and eight partially trained and <unk> divisions in Australia .
The RAAF was <unk> with <unk> aircraft , most of which were <unk> <unk> , and the &lt; unk &gt; had three cruisers and two destroyers in Australian waters .
The Australian military suffered a series of defeats during the early months of the Pacific War .
The 8th Division and RAAF squadrons in Malaya formed a part of the British Commonwealth forces which were unable to stop a smaller Japanese invasion force which landed on 7 December .
The British Commonwealth force withdrew to Singapore at the end of January , but was forced to surrender on 15 February after the Japanese captured much of the island .
<unk> Australian forces were also <unk> and defeated during early 1942 at Rabaul , and in <unk> , Timor , and Java .
The Australian town of Darwin was heavily bombed by the Japanese on 19 February , to prevent it from being used as an Allied base .
Over 22 @ , @ 000 Australians were taken prisoner in early 1942 and <unk> <unk> conditions in Japanese <unk> .
The prisoners were <unk> to &lt; unk &gt; , denied medical treatment and frequently <unk> and killed by their guards .
As a result , 8 @ , @ <unk> Australian prisoners died in <unk> .
The rapid Allied defeat in the Pacific caused many Australians to fear that the Japanese would <unk> the Australian mainland .
While elements of the Imperial Japanese Navy proposed this in early 1942 , it was <unk> to be impossible by the Japanese Imperial General Headquarters , which instead adopted a strategy of <unk> Australia from the United States by capturing New Guinea , the Solomon Islands , <unk> , Samoa , and New <unk> .
This fact was not known by the Allies at the time , and the Australian military was greatly expanded to meet the threat of invasion .
<unk> numbers of United States Army and Army Air Forces units arrived in Australia in early 1942 , and the Australian military was placed under the overall command of General Douglas <unk> in March .
Australians played a central role in the New Guinea campaign during 1942 and 1943 .
After an attempt to land troops at Port <unk> was defeated in the Battle of the <unk> Sea , the Japanese attempted to capture the <unk> important town by advancing <unk> across the <unk> Stanley <unk> and Milne Bay .

In late 1943 , the 7th and 9th <unk> played an important role in Operation &lt; unk &gt; , when they landed to the east and west of <unk> and secured the &lt; unk &gt; Peninsula during the &lt; unk &gt; Peninsula campaign and &lt; unk &gt; Range campaign .

These attacks sought to cut the Allied supply lines between Australia and the US and Australia and New Guinea , but were unsuccessful .
Japanese aircraft also conducted air raids against Allied bases in northern Australia which were being used to <unk> the North Western Area Campaign against Japanese positions in the Netherlands East Indies ( &lt; unk &gt; ) .
Australia &apos; s role in the Pacific War declined from 1944 .
The increasing size of the US forces in the Pacific <unk> the Australian military <unk> and <unk> shortages forced the Government to reduce the size of the armed forces to boost war production .

= = Post @ - @ Vietnam era = = = = = <unk> of the Australian Defence Force , 1976 = = = Although the importance of &apos; joint &apos; warfare had been <unk> during Second World War when Australian naval , ground and air units frequently served as part of single <unk> , the absence of a central authority continued to result in poor co @ - @ <unk> between the services in the post @ - @ war era , with each <unk> and operating on the basis of a different military <unk> .
The need for an integrated command structure received more emphasis during the Australian military &apos; s experiences in the Vietnam War .
In 1973 , the <unk> of the Department of Defence , Arthur &lt; unk &gt; , submitted a report to the Government that recommended the <unk> of the separate <unk> supporting each service into a single department and the creation of the post of Chief of the Defence Force Staff .
The &lt; unk &gt; Labor Government subsequently <unk> the five defence &lt; unk &gt; ( Defence , Navy , Army , Air Force , and <unk> ) into a single Department of Defence in 1973 , while <unk> under the National Service scheme was <unk> .
On 1 January 1976 , the three branches of the Australian military were brought together as a <unk> , all @ - @ volunteer , professional force known as the Australian Defence Force ( &lt; unk &gt; ) .
Today , the &lt; unk &gt; is headquartered at Russell &lt; unk &gt; in Canberra and is divided into Air , Land , <unk> and Special Operations &lt; unk &gt; .
In addition , Northern Command is based in Darwin , and is responsible for operations in Northern Australia .
= = = Defence of Australia , 1980s and 1990s = = = Until the 1970s , Australia &apos; s military strategy <unk> on the concept of <unk> Defence , in which the role of Australian military and naval forces were to co @ - @ operate with Allied forces to counter <unk> in Australia &apos; s region .
Following the <unk> of the <unk> <unk> by the United States in 1969 , and the British withdrawal &apos; east of Suez &apos; in the early 1970s , Australia developed a defence policy <unk> self @ - @ <unk> and the defence of the Australian <unk> .
<unk> as the Defence of Australia <unk> , it focused Australian defence planning on protecting the nation &apos; s northern maritime approaches ( the &apos; air @ - @ sea gap &apos; ) against possible attack .
In line with this goal , the &lt; unk &gt; was &lt; unk &gt; to increase its ability to strike at enemy forces from Australian bases and to counter raids on <unk> Australia .

= = Military statistics = = = Ward Churchill = Ward &lt; unk &gt; Churchill ( born 1947 ) is an American author and political activist .

= = &lt; unk &gt; = = Churchill &apos; s <unk> are often American Indian figures and other themes associated with Native American Culture .
He uses historical <unk> as <unk> material for works .
In the early 1990s at Santa <unk> Indian Market , Churchill <unk> the passage of the 1990 Indian Arts and &lt; unk &gt; Act .
It <unk> that , to identify and exhibit works as being by a Native American , artists and <unk> must be enrolled in a Native American tribe or designated by a tribe as an &lt; unk &gt; .
Under federal law , Churchill cannot identify his art as by a Native American .

For example , his 1981 &lt; unk &gt; Winter <unk> was , according to Churchill and others , based on a 1972 drawing by the artist Thomas E. &lt; unk &gt; Churchill printed 150 copies of Winter <unk> and sold at least one of them .

= The Boat Race 2008 = The &lt; unk &gt; Boat Race took place on 29 March 2008 .
<unk> annually , the event is a side @ - @ by @ - @ side <unk> race between crews from the <unk> of Oxford and Cambridge along the River Thames .
Oxford won the race .
Oxford &apos; s crew featured the oldest <unk> in Boat Race history .
The race took place in very difficult weather conditions – strong winds and heavy rain – resulting in the <unk> winning time in over <unk> years .
Oxford won by six lengths , the largest margin of victory since the 2004 race .
Oxford &apos; s <unk> beat Cambridge &apos; s <unk> in the reserve race , while Oxford won the Women &apos; s Boat Race .
= = Background = = The Boat Race is a side @ - @ by @ - @ side <unk> competition between the University of Oxford ( sometimes referred to as the &quot; <unk> Blues &quot; ) and the University of Cambridge ( sometimes referred to as the &quot; Light Blues &quot; ) .
First held in <unk> , the race takes place on the 4 @ .
@ 2 @ - @ mile ( 6 @ .
@ 8 km ) Championship Course on the River Thames in southwest London .
The rivalry is a major point of honour between the two <unk> and followed throughout the United Kingdom and broadcast worldwide .
Cambridge went into the race as <unk> <unk> , having <unk> Oxford by over a length in the previous year &apos; s race and the overall lead , with 79 victories to Oxford &apos; s 73 .
The race was sponsored by &lt; unk &gt; for the fourth time .
The first Women &apos; s Boat Race took place in 1927 , but did not become an annual fixture until the 1960s .
Until 2014 , the contest was conducted as part of the &lt; unk &gt; Boat <unk> , but as of the 2015 race , it is held on the River Thames , on the same day as the men &apos; s main and reserve races .
The reserve race , contested between Oxford &apos; s <unk> boat and Cambridge &apos; s <unk> boat has been held since 1965 .
It usually takes place on the &lt; unk &gt; , prior to the main Boat Race .

= Fort Scott National Historic Site = Fort Scott National Historic Site is a historical area under the control of the United States National Park Service in <unk> County , Kansas , United States .
<unk> after General <unk> Scott , who achieved &lt; unk &gt; during the Mexican @ - @ American War , during the middle of the 19th century the fort served as a military base for US Army action in what was the edge of settlement in <unk> .
For the next quarter century , it was used as a supply base and to provide security in <unk> areas during the opening of the West to settlement , a period which included <unk> Kansas and the American Civil War .
The current national historic site <unk> 20 historic structures , a <unk> ground , and five acres ( 20 @ , @ 000 m <unk> ) of restored &lt; unk &gt; <unk> , inside the city of Fort Scott .
It is open to visitors most days of the year .
= = History = = In <unk> , Fort Scott was named after <unk> Scott , was established on the American frontier on the military road in eastern Kansas between Fort &lt; unk &gt; and Fort <unk> .
It was established to provide protection to the rapidly increasing number of settlers , who were <unk> from the Eastern United States .
Fort Scott became one of a <unk> of forts intended to protect the new settlers from the <unk> Indians , as well as to protect the Indians from the settlers &apos; <unk> .
The United States government <unk> to reserve permanent Indian lands west of the Missouri River gave way to the competition of settlers continuing to &lt; unk &gt; on the Indian <unk> .
Fort Scott &apos; s most active days were between <unk> and 1853 , although it was also used during the Civil War .
= = = Army days = = = The &lt; unk &gt; of Indian Territory ( now Oklahoma ) were <unk> to have Fort <unk> in their <unk> .
After some delay , the US Army decided to abandon Fort <unk> and move its soldiers to a new fort to be built between Fort &lt; unk &gt; and the site .
The Army both wanted to &lt; unk &gt; the &lt; unk &gt; ( who were <unk> by the Department of <unk> ) and provide more defense for white settlers and other Indians against the <unk> , who had been conducting <unk> raids in the area .
On April 1 , <unk> , some soldiers of Fort <unk> left their fort and on April 22 arrived where Fort Scott would be built , in the <unk> &lt; unk &gt; section of modern @ - @ day Kansas .
After &lt; unk &gt; with the &lt; unk &gt; to <unk> the land , the rest of Fort <unk> &apos; s garrison left the fort on May 26 and arrived at the Fort Scott site on May 30 .
Unlike most forts for military use , the fort did not have defensive walls or structures when first built ; the wide @ - @ open area and the available artillery made an <unk> fort <unk> .
The soldiers concentrated on building structures for <unk> the men , animals , and equipment .
These buildings were on the edges of a 350 @ - @ foot ( 110 m ) <unk> ground .
The post &lt; unk &gt; , Captain Thomas <unk> , was in charge of building Fort Scott &apos; s structures , and had to deal with the problems of construction on the Kansas <unk> , which had few trees .
He had only two &lt; unk &gt; and three <unk> to <unk> on , as there were few civilians and most of the soldiers had other duties to perform .
Wood was available , but the mill was built 1 @ .
@ 5 miles ( 2 @ .
@ 4 km ) away , making transport time <unk> .
<unk> found his efforts <unk> by lack of wood , <unk> labor and working equipment .
<unk> <unk> destroyed much of the wood intended for the fort &apos; s construction .
As a result , only one &lt; unk &gt; of the five planned officers <unk> ( four &lt; unk &gt; and post <unk> &apos; s house ) was built by <unk> , and the intended enlisted barracks were not completed .
In his <unk> <unk> of the fort , Colonel George &lt; unk &gt; reported that , in <unk> to other frontier forts , he considered Fort Scott &quot; above average &quot; .
Due to the rising <unk> that <unk> in the Mexican @ - @ American War , the US Army <unk> troops to the <unk> .
With Fort Scott still <unk> , officials decided on April 25 , <unk> , that no more construction would be done there , after eight years and $ 35 @ , @ 000 .
By the time it was finished , it was <unk> ; three years later , it was abandoned by the military in favor of the more western Fort Riley .
For the average soldier , life at the fort was &quot; &lt; unk &gt; &quot; .
Until the permanent structures were built , soldiers had to live in <unk> , which lacked <unk> .
<unk> from a few whiskey &lt; unk &gt; and <unk> , few civilians lived at the fort .
<unk> had brought their personal <unk> with them , including Captain <unk> .
Five miles East in Missouri was a &lt; unk &gt; shop that <unk> soldiers , and quite a few courts @ - @ martial followed soldiers &apos; going &lt; unk &gt; at the shop .
